content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would consider this as a repeated game with multiple rounds. Since the payoff is higher when both players choose the same option (either R or B), it seems like there's an incentive to maintain consistency in my choice. However, the slight advantage for the opponent when they pick opposite choices (35$ vs 0$) suggests that they might exploit this inconsistency if I randomly switch between R and B.

In such a case, it would be beneficial to have a strategy that minimizes the opponent's potential gain from exploiting my inconsistencies while also maximizing my own payoff. One possible strategy could be Tit-for-Tat, where I initially choose one option (let's say R) and then stick with that choice unless my opponent switches strategies, in which case I would switch as well to punish their deviation and encourage them to return to the original choice.

In this context, if the opponent sticks to a single choice for an extended period, it would be more profitable for me to mimic their strategy, earning 40$ per round when we both pick B or 45$ when we both pick R. On the other hand, if the opponent starts deviating from a single choice and switches between R and B, I can punish that deviation by mirroring their choices with the aim of forcing them to return to their initial strategy for higher payoff in the long run.

In summary, considering the game's structure as repeated with multiple rounds and adopting a Tit-for-Tat strategy, my choice would be R{R}. This indicates that I will choose R consistently unless my opponent switches strategies, at which point I may switch to mirror their choices.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 35$. Please play the next round.

In this scenario, my opponent exploited the inconsistency in my strategy by choosing B when I chose R. As a human player adopting the Tit-for-Tat strategy, I would switch to mimic their choice for the next round to punish their deviation and encourage them to return to their initial strategy.

In this particular case, since my opponent initially chose B, it would be beneficial for me to also pick B in the subsequent round to enforce a change in their behavior. So my next choice would be B{B}. This indicates that I will switch strategies to reflect my opponent's previous choice, hoping they will reciprocate and stick with their original strategy (R) for higher payoff in the long run.
